MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: if he has any plans to increase the subsidy paid to social welfare recipients in the Dublin area to assist with the cost of smokeless fuels, especially in the light of the experience during the winter when many people found that the amount was inadequate to cover the extra costs; if there are any plans to extend the categories to which the subsidy is paid; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The additional fuel allowance of £3 per week which I introduced at the start of the 1990-91 heating season was designed to help low income households in the built up areas of Dublin meet the additional costs arising from the ban on bituminous coal. Some 74,000 households received the allowance at an estimated cost of £5.8 million in 1991. This was in addition to the provision of £29.1 million for the national fuel scheme.

The new allowance was payable to all households in the designated areas qualifying for assistance under the national fuel scheme. Such households received an allowance of £8 per week. The new allowance was also payable to people on short term unemployment assistance, unemployment benefit, disability benefit for more than three months and to recipients of family income supplement, subject to the conditions applying in the national fuel scheme.

MainHeading.P: All aspects of the ban on bituminous coal in the Dublin area are being reviewed by the Department of the Environment at present, in consultation with my Department and the Departments of Industry and Commerce, Energy and interested organisations. The question of the rate of the weekly fuel allowance is being examined in this context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Payment of Household Bills.

Qst.Quest: when he will make regulations under section 54 of the Social Welfare Act, 1991; if he intends to consult with any organisations, such as the Combat Poverty Agency or the Society of St. Vincent de Paul, prior to making regulations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: As part of the process of helping people on low incomes manage their budget as effectively as possible, I included a provision in this year's Social Welfare Act providing for the necessary regulatory powers to enable an agreed portion of a social welfare payment to be withheld with the consent of the recipient and transferred over to a specified body. The purpose of this provision, which is contained in section 54 of the Social Welfare Act, 1991, is to help recipients in the payment of certain recurring household bills such as ESB bills and local authority rents.

The scope of these regulations is currently being examined within my Department. Consultations will take place with appropriate organisations and the regulations will be made as soon as the necessary administrative arrangements are put in place.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Voluntary Social Services Charter.

Qst.Quest: the progress which has been made in regard to drawing up the Charter for Voluntary Social Services which was promised in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress; the organisations he intends to consult with in regard to the Charter; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: In keeping with the commitment in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress my Department are preparing a White Paper on the role of voluntary organisations in the social services area. This will involve drawing up a charter for voluntary social services which will set out a clear framework for partnership between the State and voluntary activity.

The White Paper will address such issues as the nature and the extent of voluntary social services activity; the supports currently provided by the State sector; the current relationships between the statutory and voluntary sectors and how the State can encourage and support voluntary activity in the social services area.

Preliminary work associated with the preparation of the White Paper has now been completed. This involved documenting the nature of voluntary activity in Ireland and the supports currently provided by the State sector. My Department have also had initial consultations with many of the key voluntary organisations in the social services area, other Government Departments and with relevant State-sponsored bodies including the Combat Poverty Agency and the National Social Services Board. In addition, discussions have also taken place between my Department and relevant statutory and voluntary organisations in Northern Ireland and in Great Britain.

An advertisement was placed in the national press on 19 May 1991, and in newsletters with a circulation to voluntary groups, inviting interested organisations and individuals to contact my Department. This will be followed by a brief questionnaire to respondents which will enable my Department compile a comprehensive profile of interested organisations working in the social services area to identify the issues which voluntary groups would wish to see addressed in the White Paper.

At the same time a number of groups, representing a cross-section of the main types of voluntary organisations in the social services area, have been approached seeking their views on the issues to be addressed in the charter.

MainHeading.P: Over the coming months, wide-ranging consultations will take place with a broad cross-section of voluntary groups throughout the country. This will be done through a series of local and regional seminars, through discussions with interested groups and individuals and through inviting written submissions from voluntary organisations who wish to put their views in writing.

Consultation will also take place with the relevant Government Departments and State agencies. I would welcome any comments in relation to the White Paper from any group or individual wishing to contribute to the process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.Quest: if he will consider the introduction of tiered rates for dependent children in view of the fact that the cost of feeding and maintaining teenage children is considerably higher than for infants or young children; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I am very aware of the financial needs of families with children and I have made significant progress in recent budgets in improving the position of such families. This has included increases in the basic rates of payments and substantial increases in child dependent payments. Child benefit payments have also been increased.

MainHeading.P: In 1987, there were 36 child dependant rates with a minimum rate of £6. In the 1991 budget, the minimum child dependant rate was increased to £12 representing a 100 per cent increase. The number of rates was streamlined to three. Also, child dependant allowances were extended to age 21 in respect of the child dependants of all long term recipients where the child remains in full-time education.

Other improvements in child-related payments were the payment of the higher child benefit of £22.90 in respect of fourth child onwards, which represents an annual increase of over £85 for families of at least four children; substantial improvements in the family income supplement scheme including an increase in the income limits and the abolition of the maximum payments — this latter improvement will be of significant help to low earners and the introduction of a back-to-school clothing and footwear allowance scheme providing for families on social welfare, up to £25 each for children in primary school and £40 for children in second level schools for back to school costs.

In addition, for families at work on low pay, the child related tax exemption scheme, with effect from 6 April 1991, provides for a child tax exemption of £300 for the first and second child in a family, and £500 for third and subsequent children.

Under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, the Government are committed to providing the resources necessary to implement the additional child income support measures recommended by the Commission on Social Welfare — some £69 million in 1990 terms — over the ten year period of the programme. The particular measures taken will be decided in the light of up-to-date information on child and family circumstances and taking account of available resources. The issue of age-related child dependant payments will be considered in that context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Means Test System.

Qst.Quest: the steps he intends to take to implement the commitment given in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress that the means test system would be streamlined to ensure a more effective and client-orientated system; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The means test criteria are broadly similar for all schemes although there are variations in the manner in which some of the components, principally capital and income from earnings are assessed. For example the rules of means assessment in the case of widows, lone parents and the elderly are generally more favourable.

As indicated in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, further attention will be given to greater integration of social assistance provisions and streamlining of means tests to ensure a more effective and client-oriented system. This will include the greater integration into the social welfare system of the supplementary welfare allowance provisions and other related provisions currently administered by the health boards. The issues are under review in my Department.

MainHeading.P: I have already in this year's budget introduced means test improvements whereby income derived from casual employment as a home-help is disregarded. A minimum weekly payment of £5 was also introduced for unemployment assistance claimants whose current entitlement is less than £5 and whose only means is the yearly value of free board and lodgings at home.

The administrative procedures for means-testing are kept under constant review with a view to reducing the need to visit claimants in their homes. Increasingly desk interviewing is being used where possible to establish means and thus reduce the time taken to put claims into payment. All social welfare officers dealing directly with claimants now carry out desk interviews at least one day per week. This has reduced considerably the need for claimants to seek supplementary welfare allowance until their claims are decided, particularly in relation to the unemployment assistance scheme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the reason a full refund has not been made and deductions continue to be made to the unemployment assistance of a person (details supplied) in County Galway on the basis of supposed earnings by his spouse from her work as a poet.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Following investigation, a deciding officer assessed the means of the person concerned at £5.00 per week from 20 November 1990. The means are derived from the benefit of his wife's income. This assessment leaves him entitled to payment at the weekly rate of £100.00.

MainHeading.P: He appealed against the decision and his case was referred to the independent social welfare appeals office for consideration. However, as he failed to supply details of his wife's income and expenditure as requested by the social welfare officer, his appeal was regarded as withdrawn by the appeals officer.

Qst.Quest: the reason school wardens have been refused permission to sign on for social welfare credits at Kilbarrack employment exchange, Dublin 5.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Under the new arrangements which I introduced earlier this year, any person who is earning over £25 a week is fully insured and covered for all the benefits of the social insurance system. Under present legislation, where no contributions were awarded for two consecutive contribution years, a credited contribution cannot be granted until the insured person has paid 26 contributions. When the people concerned have accumulated 26 paid contributions at the class A1 rate they will be entitled to the award of credited contributions for periods of proved unemployment.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the reason in considering the income level at which a partial old age non-contributory pension will be withdrawn no account is taken of the person's entitlement to a living alone allowance.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: At present, an applicant for old age non-contributory pension with assessed means of up to £6 per week can qualify for a full pension of £53 per week, £55 from later this month. Where the applicant has means in excess of £6 per week a reduced old age pension is payable depending on the amount of his means. The reduction in the basic rate of pension is £2 for each additional £2 of means.

A living alone allowance is payable in addition to the basic rate of pension if the pensioner is living alone. This is a separate allowance which does not form part of the basic pension. It is payable to all persons aged 66 or over qualifying for a social welfare pension who are living alone and is not subject to a means test. It is therefore not taken into account when determining the amount of basic pension payable in any case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Examination by Medical Referee.

Qst.Quest: if he has investigated a complaint from a person (details supplied) in Dublin 22 about the treatment she received when visiting the medical referee at Oisin House; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: Medical referees are fully qualified and experienced practitioners who provide a second opinion to that of the person's own doctor for the guidance of the Department's deciding officers. Their examinations conform to the ethical conduct and behaviour guidelines of the medical council.

The examinations conducted by medical referees are confined to establishing whether the person is incapable. Medical referees do not attempt to determine how best the case should be managed with a view to recovery and future treatment. Accordingly, some persons will notice that there are some differences between the way a general practitioner or consultant approaches their case and the type of examination made by a medical referee.

MainHeading.P: Every effort is made to ensure that the interests of persons referred for medical referee examination are fully safeguarded. Their own certifiers are advised of the forthcoming examinations and invited to submit an appropriate medical report including references to any recent consultant examinations. In addition it is open to a certifier to attend a medical referee examination if he or she so wishes.
The complaint by the person concerned has been investigated by the medical adviser who is satisfied that the medical referee concerned carried out the examination in a courteous, professional manner.

Qst.Quest: the number of persons on the live register at the end of June, 1991; the seasonally adjusted numbers unemployed; the number of persons (a) in receipt of pre-retirement benefit and (b) obtaining pre-retirement credits; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy regarding the live register was published by the Central Statistics Office on 8 July 1991. It relates to the position of the live register at 28 June 1991 and includes those who were available for and actively seeking work at that date. The total number on the live register at 28 June was 253,396. This figure includes some 11,900 students, teachers and school related persons who applied for unemployment payments, many of whom may not be eligible. Seasonally adjusted figures also included in the same Central Statistics Office statement for 28 June are 256,300.

There is no pre-retirement benefit scheme in operation in my Department. However, persons who are over age 58 and have retired from their occupations may receive pre-retirement credits. The number of people on these credits at 28 June was 3,071. In addition, persons over age 58 who are no longer actively seeking work may claim the pre-retirement allowance. The number of people on this allowance at 28 June was 6,789.
This information was included in the statement on the live register circulated to all Deputies by the Central Statistics Office on 8 July.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Report on Land Registry.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Crime Increase.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the serious public concern at the significant growth in recent months in levels of crime and vandalism in parts of Dublin; if he has asked the Garda to take any steps to deal with this in view of the serious level of fear which now exists in parts of Dublin; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if his attention has been drawn to the increase in petty crime in both rural and urban areas; the proposals he is prepared to implement in order to curtail this rise in crime; if he is prepared to increase Garda manpower on the ground; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 93 and 96 together.

MainHeading.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that provisional figures indicate that there was an increase in the level of recorded larcenies, in both urban and rural areas, in 1990 as compared with 1989. A number of measures are being taken by the Garda to deal with the problem. These include the use of additional patrols and check-points and the deployment of Garda resources to meet the special requirements of particular areas. In addition, the Garda are continuing to encourage and promote community involvement in crime-prevention activities through the community alert and neighbourhood watch schemes. The Garda authorities are monitoring the situation closely and will take whatever measures may be necessary to deal with the problem.

I am aware of public concern about the problems of crime and vandalism in certain parts of Dublin, in particular. Provisional figures for the first five months of this year show an increase in crime in certain areas. I should point out, however, that estimated figures gathered over a relatively short period cannot be regarded as being firmly indicative of a longer term trend. The Garda authorities do not await confirmation of trends before they act and they have informed me that they have already put specific measures in place in certain parts of Dublin city and elsewhere to counteract the increased incidence of crime. In addition to the general measures already described above, these specific measures include greater deployment of plain-clothes surveillance units and the targeting of Garda resources to meet specific anti-crime needs in particular areas. The Garda authorities are satisfied that these measures will prove effective in tackling the problems which have given rise to concern in certain Dublin suburbs of late.

It is important to put the problem in Dublin in perspective. The level of recorded indictable crime in the DMA decreased by approximately 8 per cent in 1989 as compared with the corresponding figures for 1988 and provisional figures indicate that the level decreased in 1990 by a further 2.9 per cent. The situation in the DMA is being very closely monitored by the Garda authorities and I am satisfied that whatever further action may be appropriate to deal with the problems in the area will be taken.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Juvenile Justice System.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the progress which has been made to date in the review of the system of juvenile justice which was referred to in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress; if he will outline the form the review is taking; when it is expected to be completed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: The reference in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress to a review of the juvenile justice system should be read in conjunction with the statement I issued on youth policy initiatives on 5 December last and the contribution which I made in this House on 20 February to the debate on the programme.

MainHeading.P: In the area of juvenile justice I am concerned to develop programmes and initiatives which will help to prevent young people from becoming involved in crime; to guide those who have started to slip into crime back to a law-abiding lifestyle; and to assist the rehabilitation of those young people who have entered the custodial system administered by the Department of Justice. To this end I initiated an ongoing review of the juvenile justice system within my Department, the early fruits of which are detailed in the statements to which I referred.
I will outline very briefly, some of the progress which has been made.

A national office to supervise the service was established last December. Juvenile liaison officers were then put on the seven day roster to facilitate evening and weekend working. The length of time spent with, and the number of visits made to, young people on the scheme will be varied to reflect the extent to which continuing supervision is required on an individual basis. Work is also at an advanced stage on new procedural guidelines for the operation of the scheme's cautioning and supervision system and a new training curriculum for juvenile liaison officers.

Based on a pilot project developed by the Garda and St. Patrick's Teacher Training College, Drumcondra, and carried out in Tallaght in 1990, a Garda schools programme, which aims to develop positive attitudes towards law enforcement and the Garda, is now in operation in 14 Dublin schools. It will be extended to Limerick, Waterford and Cork in the near future.

The probation and welfare service, with local Garda support, is actively involved in the implementation of community-based programmes designed to effectively direct youngsters away from law breaking. Already three specialised remedial projects have commenced at Cherry Orchard and in the CoolockDarndale area in Dublin and in Southhill, Limerick.

Other measures which are being taken are the assignment of extra probation and welfare officers to areas where the incidence of crime is high and the utilisation of the resources of statutory and voluntary social agencies elsewhere.

With regard to those children and young people whom the courts decide must be committed to custodial institutions, the position is that the provision of special accommodation for boys under 16 years of age and girls under 17 is a matter for the Department of Education; and my colleague, the Minister for Education, is providing additional such accommodation at Lusk, County Dublin. These places will come on stream very shortly. Young offenders over those ages for the most part detained, in the case of males, in St. Patrick's Institution and Wheatfield and, in the case of females, in the women's prison at Mountjoy. Wheatfield is a modern facility where emphasis is placed on education and work training for young offenders. An extensive programme of refurbishment of St. Patrick's and the women's prison is under way which will upgrade the facilities in those institutions.
A Juvenile Justice Bill to replace the Children's Act, 1908, is also being prepared in my Department and will be introduced in due course.

To ensure maximum co-operation between the Departments who have responsibilities for the welfare of children and young persons — i.e. the Department of Justice, Health and Education — all work in this area is being co-ordinated by an inter-departmental committee under the chairmanship of the Minister of State at the Department of Health, Deputy Chris Flood.

Qst.Quest: the reason the number of young offenders dealt with under the juvenile liaison officer scheme declined from 3,700 in 1987 to 2,700 in 1989, especially in view of the continuing problem of juvenile crime; the steps he intends to take to promote the greater use of the juvenile liaison officer scheme; when the national juvenile liaison scheme, promised in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress will be established; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: There is no quota for the number of juvenile offenders to be dealt with under the juvenile liaison officer scheme and the work involved for JLOs can vary considerably from case to case. The reduction in the number of juveniles dealt with under the scheme in 1989 as compared with 1987 owes more to the exceptional number of juveniles who were admitted to the scheme in 1987 than to any diminution in the efforts of JLOs in the later year.

The establishment of a national juvenile liaison office, which is already operational, is only one of a number of significant reforms introduced in the juvenile liaison officer scheme to enhance its operation. Other important reforms include new reporting and supervision arrangements for JLOs, flexibility in the period of supervision of youngsters, as well as restoration of weekend working and enhanced training for gardaí assigned to these duties. The combination of all these measures is intended to ensure that an improved JLO scheme is made available for all suitable young offenders.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Registry Entries.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the remedies which are available to people to gain redress, other than legal actioni, where entries in the Land Registry have been the basis for forgery or inaccuracy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: Section 32 (1) (a) of the Registration of Title Act, 1964, provides for the rectification of errors in registration originating in the Land Registry, whether by mis-statement, mis-description, omission or otherwise. Rule 8 (a) of the Land Registry Rules, 1972 provides for the correction of a clerical error in a register or registry map. Furthermore, provision is made in section 120 of the Registration of Title Act, 1964, and Part V of the Land Registration Rules, 1972, for compensation payable out of the Central Fund for error, forgery or fraud in relation to registration.

MainHeading.P: Persons becoming aware of errors in entries in the Land Registry records should notify the Registrar of Titles, Land Registry, giving appropriate details.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Life Expectancy.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the recent report produced by the British Department of Health which shows that the life expectancy of a woman in Ireland is the worst of 15 developed countries and that the life expectancy for Irish men is fourth worst of the 15 countries surveyed; if he intends to carry out any investigation as to the reasons for this situation; if he intends to take any steps to try to improve life expectancy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I recognise that the health statue of Irish people and their life expectancy could be improved. I have, on many occasions, drawn attention to this fact. Indeed it has been the rationale behind many of the intitiatives I have taken in the last few years, particularly in the area of health promotion.

MainHeading.P: It was in recognition of the fact that we needed greater co-ordination in our efforts to promote the health of our community and, by implication, improve life expectancy, that I reorganised the health promotion structures at national level. As the Deputy is aware, the health promotion framework now has four main elements: a Cabinet subcommittee to ensure that the policies of relevant Government Departments support health, an Advisory Council on Health Promotion to make recommendations to me on priorities in this area, a Health Promotion Unit — the executive and policy formulation function at national level — and, most recently, a chair of health promotion in University College Galway to provide a teaching and research resource in health promotion.

As the Deputy is aware, the major causes of death, including premature deaths, in Ireland, as in many developed countries, are heart disease and cancer. Most recent available statistics show that in 1989 diseases of the heart and circulatory system accounted for 47 per cent of all deaths. Cancer is the second leading cause of death, accounting for 23 per cent of deaths. These diseases can be viewed as major contributors to our unfavourable life expectancy. As a country we compare quite favourably with countries such as Italy, France, Spain and Belgium in terms of the number of deaths from coronary heart disease and stroke in men in the 30-69 year age group, for example. Other countries such as Finland, America and Canada, have achieved significant reductions in coronary heart disease. Some of this reduction is attributed to community-based projects aimed at reducing the risk factors for coronary heart disease — smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol levels, alcohol abuse — and encouraging healthy lifestyles.

For this reason the Kilkenny Health Project was initiated as a major pilot project with a brief to develop, implement and evaluate a communitybased health promotion programme to prevent cardiovascular disease. The programme is now being evaluated both in terms of its effect on the lifestyle of the people of County Kilkenny and also in terms of its potential for integration into the health service structures nationwide having regard to such matters as feasibility and cost effectiveness.

Lifestyle behaviours such as smoking are risk factors not only for heart disease and stroke but also for some cancers, most notably lung cancer, and for diseases like bronchitis and emphysema. Other lifestyle factors implicated in the causation of preventable diseases are alcohol abuse, lack of exercise and unhealthy food choices.

The Health Promotion Unit have invested significant funds in the development of a lifewise programme which address these issues. Lifewise is a health education programme for adults which focuses on promoting healthy behaviour and provides the individual with the skills, information and motivation to develop and maintain a healthy lifestyle. An important feature of the programme is its flexibility for use in a variety of settings. The programme is being piloted in the Mid-Western Health Board and because of its success to date a number of other boards, viz. North-East-ern, Midland, Southern and South-Eastern, have asked to be party to the programme. A new training programme was recently arranged involving participants from all the interested boards and also from the Irish Countrywomen's Association. A national structure to oversee the development of the project and ensure its quality is being developed.

In relation to alcohol, a comprehensive national policy on alcohol is currently being developed under the aegis of the Advisory Council on Health Promotion. This policy will examine the broad range of social, cultural, economic, legal and educational issues involved and will pay particular attention to the question of youth and alcohol. A number of initiatives have already been taken in relation to alcohol use by young people — most significantly the launch of the Drink Awareness for Youth Programme aimed at 14-19 year olds to encourage them to make responsible decisions about alcohol use.

Another important feature of the health promotion unit's activities each year is an anti-smoking campaign. A legislative framework which supports health promotion programmes is an important component in a strategy to improve health status. In that regard the anti-smoking legislation which we have introduced should make a significant contribution in the long term to reducing deaths from smoking, of which there are currently 5,000 per year in Ireland. I am also confident that the increase of 10p in the price of a packet of 20 cigarettes introduced by the Government in the January budget will help in this regard.

I have also recently established a Nutrition Advisory Group under the aegis of the Advisory Council on Health Promotion to provide expert advice to my Department and to the general public in the area of nutrition and to combat misinformation. The unit have also developed a nutrition health promotion five-year framework for action, which was launched on 2 July 1991. There is now persuasive evidence to link unhealthy food choices to ill-health. The cornerstone of the framework for action will be the promotion of my Department's healthy eating guidelines among various targeted groups in the community.

The Health Promotion Unit provide financial support to a wide range of voluntary organisations and also have a public information service through which a variety of education materials on health topics are made available free to the public.

I might add that several of the projects carried out by the unit are taking place under the auspices of the Europe against Cancer Programme, which aims to reduce deaths from cancer by 15 per cent in the European region by the year 2000.

The Health Promotion Unit are also liaising with relevant organisations such as the Health and Safety Authority in pursuing the commitment which the Government gave under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress to utilise the potential offered by the workplace to promote healthy lifestyles.

I am confident that the health promotion measures I have outlined, together with the maintenance of a high quality health service, will lead to improvements in the health status — including life expectancy — of our population in the coming years.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Asthma Study.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the findings of the Kiely study on asthma in children which found that asthma was seriously undertreated in Irish children; if he intends to initiate or support any information and educational campaigns on the condition; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

whether his attention has been drawn to the results of a study by the Asthma Society which revealed that undertreatment is a major problem in asthmatic children with serious consequences; and if, in view of this evidence, he will consider including asthma in the list of long-term illnesses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I propose taking Questions Nos. 129 and 130 together. I am aware of the study carried out by Dr. Kiely as part of a personal research project and which is currently being submitted to a medical journal for publication. Figures on the prevalence of asthma very considerably depending on the population studied and the diagnostic criteria used. The report highlights the important role of information and education in the early diagnosis and treatment of asthma. In recognition of such a role, the Health Promotion Unit of my Department have provided substantial funding to the Asthma Society of Ireland for the production of a comprehensive information booklet on asthma which incorporates advice on the causes, prevention and treatment of asthma together with information on the effective medications now available.

It is not my intention to include asthma in the long-term illness scheme. The current general medical services scheme, the drug cost subsidisation scheme and the drugs refund scheme cater for the needs of asthma sufferers.

MainHeading.P: A major new department of respiratory medicine, with a special interest in the treatment of asthma, was officially opened recently at the James Connolly Memorial Hospital, Blanchardstown, Dublin, which will provide facilities for testing, examining and educating patients, including children, suffering from asthma and other respiratory ailments. This new unit represents a significant enhancement of the present range of services for asthma patients.

Qst.Quest: if his Department intend to initiate a programme of inoculation of children against Hepatitis B in view of the reported recommendations of the World Health Organization that all children under 12 should be immunised; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: As the Deputy may be aware, my Department have introduced guidelines recommending that all health care staff who have regular contact with blood and are at risk from personal occupational injury should be vaccinated against Hepatitis B.
There is a very low incidence of the hepatitis B virus amongst children in Ireland and consequently the introduction of a national immunisation programme is not planned at this stage.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teenage Sex Offenders' Treatment Programme.

Qst.Quest: if he intends to take any steps to ensure that a specific programme of treatments is introduced for teenagers convicted for the sexual abuse of children, similar to the one now operated for adults by the Eastern Health Board; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I understand from the Eastern Health Board that out-patient treatment for adolescent sexual abusers is provided by the board's forensic psychiatric service on an individual basis. The board hope to introduce a more structured programme within the next few months. In addition, a pilot project involving the Mater Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Service, Temple Street Hospital and the Eastern Health Board, who provide a treatment service for a number of adolescent abusers, has recently commenced. The need to provide a similar service in other health board areas will be kept under review.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in Dublin 7 had his medical card withdrawn; and if the position will now be reviewed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Qst.Quest: when persons (details supplied) in County Cavan will be called for orthodontic treatment; if his attention has been drawn to the seriousness of the cases; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

They will be assessed again on reaching sixth class, in accordance with my Department's guidelines for the provision of orthodontic treatment. The optimum age for the provision of orthodontic treatment is usually 12 to 14 years.
I understand that the health board have explained the position to the parents.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. O'Sullivan Mr. G. O'Sullivan

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Qst.Quest: if, in relation to his commitment on the Adjournment debate in Dáil Éireann on 21 May 1991 to investigate the circumstances of the committal and discharge of a woman at St. Patrick's Hospital as a matter of urgency, he will outline the reason this has not been completed; the reason the victim of this committal has not been interviewed for the investigation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: As soon as I became aware of the concern of the Deputy and of others about this case, I asked the inspector of mental hospitals to investigate the circumstances surrounding the women's detention and subsequent discharge. The inspector is preparing a thorough report. It cannot be completed until he has received a statement from all the parties with statutory obligations in the referral and detention of the woman to St. Patrick's Hospital under the procedures of the Mental Treatment Act, 1945. I understand that the inspector is still awaiting one statement before finalising his report.
It would be inappropriate of me to comment on the other issue raised by the Deputy until I receive the inspector's report.

Qst.Quest: if, in relation to his reply to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 71 to 74 of 29 May 1991, he will now give the promised figure for the number of involuntary admissions in which people spent six months or more in hospital, as this figure has not been disclosed to date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: The information is being assembled and will be sent to the Deputy in due course.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I have been informed by the North-Western Health Board that at a meeting on 19 July 1991 they will consider a notice under section 83 of the 1946 Local Government Act regarding the disposal of part of the St. Columba's Hospital property in Sligo, the old 19th century building. Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that understaffing is causing severe pressure on the nurses in St. John's Hospital, Sligo; and if he has any plans to remedy the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I have been informed by the North-Western Health Board that there is an agreement between the contractor, design team and the board that the contract for the day care centre at Tubbercurry will be completed by April 1992. It is anticipated that the centre should be functional shortly afterwards following equipping.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether he believes it would be possible to develop a care service modelled on that of the Peto Institute in Hungary for children with a handicap which affords conductive education to such children and has a good success record; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: As I indicated in a reply to a similar question on 28 February 1991, the system of conductive education developed by the Peto Institute in Hungary has been carefully examined by professional staff from the voluntary organisations providing services for children with handicaps who have been to Hungary to study their methods and approach. They consider that the system has some helpful approaches to offer and are incorporating these into their programmes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the closure of a special pre-school facility for spina bifida children at Finglas national school, Dublin 11; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. O'Sullivan Mr. G. O'Sullivan
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the projected salaries of the new posts being created by the Southern Health Board in Cork Regional Hospital for (1) a deputy general manager, (2) finance manager, (3) servicing manager, (4) personnel manager and (5) information services manager; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: In line with Government policy, and as indicated in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress, my Department are in the process of introducing alternative management structures in a number of key hospitals, including Cork Regional Hospital. The aim of this strategy is to improve the overall effectiveness of health service management and thus contribute to a more efficient use of scarce resources. The salaries are commensurate with the level of responsibility and accountability which attach to the posts. Salaries are in the range of £23,256 to £28,499 for all posts with the exception of the deputy general manager. In the case of the latter post the salary is somewhat higher, reflecting the higher duties involved.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications
Qst.Quest: if he has taken any special precautions to ensure the delays encountered by Irish holidaymakers at airports over the past number of tourist seasons will not be repeated this year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Transport and Communications (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will appreciate, I am totally averse to delays being caused to air travellers regardless of whether they are tourists or at what period of the year they are travelling.

I am hopeful that there will be few, if any, delays due to Irish Air Traffic Control during coming months. The capacity of the Irish ATC system has been considerably expanded through a £30 million re-equipment programme and an intensive recruitment programme that has increased ATC staffing from 220 officers in 1989 to 273 staff at present. Aviation is, of course, an international activity and delays may arise due to infrastructural or congestion problems in other countries.

To eliminate the delays that occur outside Irish airspace, I have been pressing through our membership of the European Civil Aviation Conference (ECAC) and of Eurocontrol, the European ATC Agency, for the necessary action to be taken rapidly to relieve air traffic congestion in Europe. Eurocontrol are at present, at the request of the ECAC Ministers of Transport, engaged in major staff recruitment and investment programmes aimed at bringing about the expansion of air traffic control capacity in Europe as rapidly as possible.
